It looks like a regression issue. When creating and starting a new service (a FTP server for example), a "Multiple Errors have Occurred" window pops up showing NPE. It can be reproduced with Eclipse 3.3M5 and the latest CVS version (also the latest N-build: N20070219-0100). It looks to me something related with changing to the "life" icons.

The exceptions are:

org.eclipse.swt.SWTException: Failed to execute runnable (java.lang.NullPointerException)
at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3478)
at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3401)
at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Synchronizer.runAsyncMessages(Synchronizer.java:126)
at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.runAsyncMessages(Display.java:3467)
at org.eclipse.swt.widgets.Display.readAndDispatch(Display.java:3107)
at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runEventLoop(Workbench.java:2264)
at org.eclipse.ui.internal.Workbench.runUI(Workbench.java:2228)
[...]

Seen the same with ssh. At the time an ssh file service connects to the remote side, the error dialog is shown.

I tracked down the NPE down to
SystemView.updateRemoteObjectProperties(Object) line: 2641	

ISystemRemoteElementAdapter	rmtAdapter = 
   (ISystemRemoteElementAdapter)((IAdaptable)remoteObject)
       .getAdapter(ISystemRemoteElementAdapter.class);

when remoteObject == FileServiceSubSystem, rmtAdapter==null which leads to the NPE. Apparently, there is no ISystemRemoteElementAdapter registered for the FileServiceSubsystem.

My naive guess would be that we'd want .getAdapter(ISystemViewElementAdapter) and in fact it might have been that way before (regression), but I had no easy access to the SystemView History.

The problem is that the code was using the existence of ISystemRemoteElementAdapter to determine whether there were remote properties to update or not.  When I changed the event code to use the ISystemViewElementAdapter, this check was last.  I've changed it now to check for remote adapter before calling updateRemoteObjectProperties().
